subject: Sleep
title: Racing Mind vs Tired Body in ADHD
description: One-minute skill: Racing Mind vs Tired Body in ADHD.

hook.text: Your body is exhausted but your ADHD brain just found a fascinating new topic at 11 PM. Sleep can wait, right?

buildup.text: ADHD involves difficulty disengaging from stimulating activities, a feature of impaired executive function.

discovery.text: The prefrontal cortex that should say 'stop and sleep' is the same region weakened by ADHD.

twist.text: Hyperfocus at night is particularly problematic because there are fewer external cues to interrupt it.

climax.text: External structure like alarms, automatic screen locks, and partner reminders substitute for weak internal brakes.

punchline.text: ADHD makes the brain's off switch unreliable, especially at bedtime.

quiz.question: Why do people with ADHD struggle to stop activities at bedtime?
options: The prefrontal cortex that controls disengagement is weakened by ADHD
